Midra, Lord of Frenzied Flame is an optional Boss found in the Abyssal Woods region of the Shadow of the Erdtree DLC.

He is the final boss of the Midra's Manse Minor Dungeon.

Check out our boss strategy below to learn how to beat this great foe: How to Reach Midra's Manse  First off, make sure you have the Map: Abyss, found in the Abyssal Woods.

You can reach this map fragment using our walkthrough here .  

Also be sure to grab the two Scadutree Fragments from inside the church next to the map stele!

Abandoned Church Scadutree Fragment From the Map Stele, we need to make our way all the way across the Abyssal Woods to the southwest corner where the Manse is located.  

You will have to run past a couple of Winter Lanterns along the way.

These enemies chase you relentlessly if they spot you, and kill you instantly if they grab you.  

You can choose to just run past them, or you can actually kill them if you parry their grab using a shield with Carian Retaliation.

The timing is hard, but you need to hit the parry after the Lantern lifts its wand in the air and as it reaches out toward you.  

Keep running west, through the fog and into this wooded corner of the map.

You will see the manse in the distance.

You will need to complete the short dungeon to reach Midra at the end.

Midra, Lord of Frenzied Flame Boss Fight Strategy Guide  Recommended Scadutree Blessing 10 - 12 Before the battle starts, you have to kill Midra in his wretch form.

He can actually deal somewhat significant damage with his grab and swiping attacks, so try to just lay into him with a bunch of quick attacks and kill him before he can retaliate.

There is a small opening after he dies to heal or buff yourself before the true form begins.

Midra, Lord of Frenzied Flame is a humanoid enemy wielding a large two hand sword and a variety of madness inducing magic.

His attacks deal both physical and holy damage, so if you are using a shield expect to take some chip damage depending on the damage negation.  

Many of Midra’s attacks also inflict Madness.

If Madness is triggered you are likely to die instantly due to the long period of vulnerability afterwards.

Equipping gear with high Focus, like the Clarifying Horn Charm, will help reduce build up.  

Midra is an offensive powerhouse, but is susceptible to some of our favorite effects: Bleed and Stagger.

With the Axe Talisman and a heavy weapon, Midra can be staggered in as few as 3-4 charge attacks, allowing you to keep him stunlocked for large portions of the battle.

If you react quickly you even have just enough time to drink one Flask before triggering the critical attack.

Consider equipping the Stonebarbed and Spiked Cracktear to your Wondrous Physick for their charge attack boosting properties.  

Midra will always open the battle with the same attack, two bursts of Frenzy flames from his “head”.

Watch the center of the head closely, there is a flash of light right before the burst comes out, that is when you want to roll toward him.

If you move quickly you can actually run up and get behind Midra before the second burst happens, allowing you to get a full charge attack on him before the battle even begins.  

Midra’s most common melee attack is a three swing combo.

He raises his sword above and behind his head before swinging down.

After a short delay, he follows it with two quicker swings.

Dodge roll toward him as each swing comes down, then after the final swing you can land an attack.  

Another is his oddly weak offhand stab.

Midra raises the dagger in his offhand above his head, then stabs downward.

This move is quick, and deals pretty negligible damage.

Dodge roll toward Midra as the dagger comes down and you can get in a quick attack before he regains composure.

Keep an eye out though, because he will occasionally follow one stab immediately with another.

One of Midra’s more strange combos is when he raises his sword up high, in front of his face, then does a sweeping swing.

Grab the item from the chandelier, a Revered Spirit Ash .  

Return to the grace and prepare yourself for a boss fight.

When you are ready, go through the door to the right and around the corner to reach the boss room.

When you first enter you will need to kill the weak enemy waiting inside.

There is a small opening after he dies to heal or buff yourself before the true form begins.

One of Midra’s more strange combos is when he raises his sword up high, in front of his face, then does a sweeping swing.

He follows this with a burst of frenzy flames, then another slow, heavy swing in front of him.

It can be easy to confuse this with the other three hit combo, but the good news is usually the mixup will only result in you getting hit by the madness burst which does relatively low damage.

Just make sure you adjust your gameplan to avoid the third swing.  

When Midra raises his sword horizontally in front of his face, he is about to do a quick two hit combo, then follow it up with a long range dash attack that leaves a trail of flames behind him.  

Make sure you roll away from the trail of flames, or else you can take damage from the as they fizzle out.  

From a distance Midra has a few different gap closing moves.

First up is a simple long range thrust, telegraphed by him raising his sword up pointed forward.

Roll into the thrust to avoid it.

One of Midra’s more strange combos is when he raises his sword up high, in front of his face, then does a sweeping swing.

He follows this with a burst of frenzy flames, then another slow, heavy swing in front of him.

It can be easy to confuse this with the other three hit combo, but the good news is usually the mixup will only result in you getting hit by the madness burst which does relatively low damage.

Just make sure you adjust your gameplan to avoid the third swing.  

When Midra raises his sword horizontally in front of his face, he is about to do a quick two hit combo, then follow it up with a long range dash attack that leaves a trail of flames behind him.  

Make sure you roll away from the trail of flames, or else you can take damage from the as they fizzle out.  

From a distance Midra has a few different gap closing moves.

First up is a simple long range thrust, telegraphed by him raising his sword up pointed forward.

Roll into the thrust to avoid it.  

For the other, Midra lights off the ground and floats in the air momentarily, before flying toward you with a wide sweeping slash.

This is another roll toward, then attack from behind.  

Another flying attack is Midra’s spinning combo.

He will do a slow twirl, holding his sword out, before quickly unleashing two spinning slashes.

He then stops momentarily, before doing another three spins.

The timing on this one is a little odd, but generally you just want to roll toward Midra two times as the spins begin, trying to end up behind him.  

One of Midra’s most damaging moves is his jumping stab.

After leaping into the air, Midra does a powerful downward thrust.

If you are caught by this stab you get brutally skewered by his spiny sword (cool to see at least once), taking massive damage.

As with most of these command grab-esque super attacks, if you dodge into it just before impact you can avoid the damage and get a couple of attacks in while Midra is standing back up.

Midra will also mix in various frenzied flame spells.

There are two versions of this: Midra leans his head forward, unleashing a single burst of frenzy flames.

When Midra spreads his arms, he is doing the long range version that covers the entire area in front of him, same as the one from the start of the battle.

Both versions are avoided by rolling into the burst as it comes out, but the quick one can be hard to see coming.  

At about 60% health Midra will enter phase two with a new attack.

He hits a t-pose and slowly floats into the air, his head becoming increasingly fiery.

He then dives into the ground, creating a massive explosion.

As soon as you see him start floating you want to run as far away as possible.

Once the explosion happens, you can run back in and do a jump attack combo as Midra slowly stands back up (this only applies to the first time Midra uses this attack.

Subsequent uses he seems to stand up much faster).  

From this point forward many of Midra’s sword attacks are augmented with flame, meaning some of his basic attacks build towards Madness.

He also has a bunch of new attacks that revolve around Madness flames.  

Some of his attacks from phase one also have new extensions.

For example, his thrust now has a follow up where his sword bursts open, creating a second, wider hitbox.

Another is his powerful leaping stab, which now has a spiky burst around it if he misses the initial stab.

This means you will want to dodge away from the initial stab, wait for the burst, then follow up with a jumping attack.  

When Midra points his sword outward and it becomes wrapped in flame he is about to unleash a ground targeted flame attack.

He will slash, and a wave of flames shoot out across the ground in a cone shape.

Thankfully this is pretty easy to avoid, you can simply roll into the wave of flames as they do not linger long enough to deal damage afterwards.
